text: <@U04V2A679>: you also need to set smaller size to last two digits for SuperscriptSpan to work

result.setSpan(new RelativeSizeSpan(0.8f), length - indexFinish, length, Spannable.SPAN_EXCLUSIVE_EXCLUSIVE);
result.setSpan(new SuperscriptSpan(), length - indexFinish, length, 0);

text: <@U0E4R68CV|jturolla> has joined the channel

<@U0DTGSP8E>: you are trying to cast DrawerLayout to RelativeLayout, they are different classes and do not reassemble parent/child inheritance, so you get "java.lang.ClassCastException: android.support.v4.widget.DrawerLayout cannot be cast to android.widget.RelativeLayout"
<@U061HDV96>:   Just wanna try to make it in single view to have as less view as possible.
I found this <http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23990381/how-to-create-vertically-aligned-superscript-and-subscript-in-textview>. it should work tho

text: Hm, let’s try
How can i achieve this?
you need to set and track the request_code
that’s how you pass and receive data when using startActivityForResult
google have changed how services integrate. They now use a gradle plugin + a json file to configure any services you use
that xml file is now auto generated by the plugin
that’s old
I think
well we integrated GA into our app a while ago and never really paid much attention to it, other than updating the play services versions
first time I saw that was integrating GCM
It used to be a pain, it’s now easy’n'smooth
I implemented something not so long ago and it didn’t need it
but all info is spread and docs are outdated all around
I think Google still hasn’t defined a way to use different json file for different flavors?
of course not :simple_smile:
tbh, it’s probably in the plugin dsl somewhere
but no one bothered to document that

text: I am going to start developing a new app. I haven’t tried any of the architectures: MVP, MVVM, Clean architechture. Would you strongly suggest to use any of these ?
Does Rx-reactive also come under this list ?
Rx has nothing to do with any of that
if you've never worked with any architecture like that elsewhere, start with the one that makes the most sense to you
i don't think there's one that's a "right" answer or anything like that
Ok Thanks
<@U0E5TKFU2|asadmshah> has joined the channel
<@U0E5XBL74|chadlindstrom> has joined the channel
<@U055GGAHS>: how do pass arbitrary data to the camera intent and allow me to receive it via the `onActivityResult` method?
you pass a request_code which is returned to you
you can’t put random data, nor should you, into intents and expect it to come back
<@U055GGAHS>: i want to be passing some data from a retrofit service. i dont know what it could be
i just need it to be associated with the photo for post processing
then you have to be responsible for keeping that information around until you get a result from the initial call
put it in a local variable and recover later, you can’t pass it to camera and expect a black box to retorn it
drat, thats what im already doing.. thanks
when calling startActivityForResult you can not make any assumptions other than that it will return something with a result and the request code
you can’t jam arbitrary data into the start intent
(well you can but it’ll just get GC’d on the other end)
the only exception being some activities may be nice and return the sending bundle in the response but you cant really rely on that
i was hoping for that
why? If you can send your data in an intent you can just as easily save it and restore it in the save/restore instance callbacks

what in particular are you trying to make “go faster"
thats kind of a broad question
are you referring to gradle build and app deployment steps?
or the vm’s that come pre-packaged with AS?
the answer is basically get whatever CPU has the fastest single core speed and that is how you  make android studio go faster
